title: How to Make Greek Style Quesadillas

steps.headline: Spray one side of each tortilla.
steps.description: To keep the tortilla from sticking, use cooking spray on one side. If you're using a nonstick pan, this step may not be necessary. Place the cooking-spray side face down on a plate or cutting board so you can add ingredients. Repeat with the other tortillas.

steps.headline: Add the ingredients.
steps.description: Sprinkle in a fourth of the chicken, feta, cucumber, onion, olives, tomatoes, parsley, and oregano. Keep it on one half of the tortilla. Sprinkle on a bit of the vinaigrette dressing. Fold the tortilla in half, covering the ingredients. Repeat with the other tortillas. You can add in roasted red pepper or a bit of fresh spinach. You can also substitute dried spices for the fresh spices. Adding a bit of mozzarella will help the quesadillas stick together better. In place of the chicken, you can use cooked ground lamb or even gyro meat.

steps.headline: Cook the quesadillas.
steps.description: Place a nonstick skillet over medium heat. Let it heat up for a minute or so. Place two quesadillas in the pan. Cook them for two to three minutes on each side, letting them brown. Take them out, and keep them warm on a baking sheet in a 300 degree Fahrenheit (149 degrees Celsius) oven while you do the other two. Cut them into wedges and serve.

steps.headline: Roast the garlic.
steps.description: Place the garlic on a small baking tray. Don't peel the garlic, but they should be individual cloves, not a head. Use a couple of tablespoons of olive oil to coat the garlic, and stick them in the oven at 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) for 25 minutes or until the garlic is soft. Once the garlic is cool, peel the cloves, and set them aside in a small bowl.

steps.headline: Make a Greek salad.
steps.description: Slice the onion thinly. Peel and slice the cucumber, making sure to scoop out the seeds to throw away. Place them in a bowl. Add the red wine vinegar, several tablespoons of olive oil, and the sesame seeds. Let the salad marinate for about 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Create flavored cream cheese.
steps.description: Add the room-temperature cream cheese to the bowl of roasted garlic. Roughly chop up the olives, and add them to the mixture. Mix the ingredients together thoroughly, making sure to get the garlic and olives all throughout the cream cheese.

steps.headline: Layer the quesadillas.
steps.description: On the inside of one piece of pita bread, spread out 1/4 of the cream cheese mixture. Do the same to three more pieces. Drain the salad, and divide it out among the pita halves. Add the cheese on top of the vegetables, then place the other halves of the pita bread on top. Chopped spinach also makes a good addition. You can use any cheese that melts well, such as cheddar, mozzarella, or monterey jack. You can also add some feta cheese.

steps.headline: Cook the quesadillas.
steps.description: Heat a skillet over medium heat for a minute or so. Butter the top off of one pita quesadilla, then place it face down in the skillet. Butter the other side. Heat for two to three minutes on each side until it's lightly brown and the cheese melts. Remove it when it's done. Cook the others the same way. Slice them into wedges, and top with red bell pepper strips. You can keep them warm on a baking sheet in a 300 degree Fahrenheit (149 degree Celsius) oven.

steps.headline: Prepare the cucumber.
steps.description: Wash the cucumber thoroughly. Peel the cucumber, then slice it in half. Scoop out the seeds, and throw them away. Grate the cucumber finely. Once it's grated, put it in a strainer, and drain off any extra juice. Place it in a bowl.

steps.headline: Mix the ingredients together.
steps.description: Add the lemon juice, lemon zest, dill, and Greek yogurt to the bowl. Finely mince the garlic, and add it, too. Add in a sprinkle of salt, and grind in some fresh pepper. Mix the ingredients together thoroughly.

steps.headline: Let it sit.
steps.description: You need to give the flavors a chance to meld in the dip. Let it chill in the refrigerator for several hours. For an even better flavor, consider letting it sit overnight in the fridge without the cucumber. Add the cucumber at the last minute the next day. Also, hold the fresh dill back, as the flavor can grow over time.

steps.headline: Use it as a topping.
steps.description: You can swirl in some olive oil at the end for additional flavor. A sprinkling of fresh mint can also be a nice addition. Some people also add a touch of plain white vinegar in place of the lemon juice, if you prefer.

text: Making Easy Greek Quesadillas Spray one side of each tortilla. To keep the tortilla from sticking, use cooking spray on one side. If you're using a nonstick pan, this step may not be necessary. Place the cooking-spray side face down on a plate or cutting board so you can add ingredients. Repeat with the other tortillas. Add the ingredients. Sprinkle in a fourth of the chicken, feta, cucumber, onion, olives, tomatoes, parsley, and oregano. Keep it on one half of the tortilla. Sprinkle on a bit of the vinaigrette dressing. Fold the tortilla in half, covering the ingredients. Repeat with the other tortillas. You can add in roasted red pepper or a bit of fresh spinach. You can also substitute dried spices for the fresh spices. Adding a bit of mozzarella will help the quesadillas stick together better. In place of the chicken, you can use cooked ground lamb or even gyro meat. Cook the quesadillas. Place a nonstick skillet over medium heat. Let it heat up for a minute or so. Place two quesadillas in the pan. Cook them for two to three minutes on each side, letting them brown. Take them out, and keep them warm on a baking sheet in a 300 degree Fahrenheit (149 degrees Celsius) oven while you do the other two. Cut them into wedges and serve. Cooking Vegetarian Greek Quesadillas Roast the garlic. Place the garlic on a small baking tray. Don't peel the garlic, but they should be individual cloves, not a head. Use a couple of tablespoons of olive oil to coat the garlic, and stick them in the oven at 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) for 25 minutes or until the garlic is soft. Once the garlic is cool, peel the cloves, and set them aside in a small bowl. Make a Greek salad. Slice the onion thinly. Peel and slice the cucumber, making sure to scoop out the seeds to throw away. Place them in a bowl. Add the red wine vinegar, several tablespoons of olive oil, and the sesame seeds. Let the salad marinate for about 30 minutes. Create flavored cream cheese. Add the room-temperature cream cheese to the bowl of roasted garlic. Roughly chop up the olives, and add them to the mixture. Mix the ingredients together thoroughly, making sure to get the garlic and olives all throughout the cream cheese. Layer the quesadillas. On the inside of one piece of pita bread, spread out 1/4 of the cream cheese mixture. Do the same to three more pieces. Drain the salad, and divide it out among the pita halves. Add the cheese on top of the vegetables, then place the other halves of the pita bread on top. Chopped spinach also makes a good addition. You can use any cheese that melts well, such as cheddar, mozzarella, or monterey jack. You can also add some feta cheese. Cook the quesadillas. Heat a skillet over medium heat for a minute or so. Butter the top off of one pita quesadilla, then place it face down in the skillet. Butter the other side. Heat for two to three minutes on each side until it's lightly brown and the cheese melts. Remove it when it's done. Cook the others the same way. Slice them into wedges, and top with red bell pepper strips. You can keep them warm on a baking sheet in a 300 degree Fahrenheit (149 degree Celsius) oven. Making Tzatziki Sauce Prepare the cucumber. Wash the cucumber thoroughly. Peel the cucumber, then slice it in half. Scoop out the seeds, and throw them away. Grate the cucumber finely. Once it's grated, put it in a strainer, and drain off any extra juice. Place it in a bowl. Mix the ingredients together. Add the lemon juice, lemon zest, dill, and Greek yogurt to the bowl. Finely mince the garlic, and add it, too. Add in a sprinkle of salt, and grind in some fresh pepper. Mix the ingredients together thoroughly. Let it sit. You need to give the flavors a chance to meld in the dip. Let it chill in the refrigerator for several hours. For an even better flavor, consider letting it sit overnight in the fridge without the cucumber. Add the cucumber at the last minute the next day. Also, hold the fresh dill back, as the flavor can grow over time. Use it as a topping. You can swirl in some olive oil at the end for additional flavor. A sprinkling of fresh mint can also be a nice addition. Some people also add a touch of plain white vinegar in place of the lemon juice, if you prefer.
